Fashion for fashion’s sake is fine, but there’s something so rich about clothing with a history, especially a sporty one. There’s the tennis polo designed by Rene Lacoste that sparked a massive athleisure trend, and then there’s the coach jacket. Also called stadium jackets, coach jackets were worn by—you guessed it—track and field coaches throughout the ’60s and ’70s to withstand inclement weather and promote ease of movement. Like varsity jackets, the best coach jackets have several distinctive features, including a loose shape that is wide around the torso, a lay-down collar, snap closures, and a drawstring base at the waist. Typically, they’re made from nylon for water resistance and durability out on the field. Nowadays, you can expect some slight variations in features, but the overall idea is the same: a jacket that plays well and looks downright cool while you do it. Whether you want to touch on the trend for cheap or are considering a more durable staple, we have the very best coach jackets laid out for you. Let’s take a peek at the top 10 below. Key Takeaways  For this assignment, I began by poring over hundreds of photos, customer reviews, and even my own closet (and my partner’s) until I whittled it down to the 10 finalists you see on this list. Overall, the best men’s coach jacket is the Stance Coaches Jacket because it’s well-priced, has the perfect shape and fit, and is doubly water-repellent. For a label-free option lined with cotton jersey for added warmth, look no further than Los Angeles Apparel Nylon Raglan Coaches Jacket. Fashion for fashion’s sake is fine, but there’s something so rich about clothing with a history, especially a sporty one. Also called stadium jackets, coach jackets were worn by—you guessed it—track and field coaches throughout the ’60s and ’70s to withstand inclement weather and promote ease of movement.

Like varsity jackets, the best coach jackets have several distinctive features, including a loose shape that is wide around the torso, a lay-down collar, snap closures, and a drawstring base at the waist. Typically, they’re made from nylon for water resistance and durability out on the field. Nowadays, you can expect some slight variations in features, but the overall idea is the same: a jacket that plays well and looks downright cool while you do it.
